questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer visits a psychiatry clinic as he is suffering from sleep disturbances due to stress in his current job from past 3 months. He cannot work properly and having difficulty to balance family and work. He has no prior psychiatric history. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adjustment disorder
• Stress factor (job) related anxiety and depressive symptoms , making it difficult to work for him is suggestive of diagnosis of adjustment disorder.
• In generalized anxiety disorder, free floating anxiety is seen.
• PTSD and Acute stress disorder are diagnosed after a sudden life threatening stress/trauma.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency with history of IV drug abuse and developed infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

S. Aureus

Whenever the question says diabetes or I/V drug abusers, think of 2 bact:-
Staph aureus & pseudomonas aeruginosa

choices.text: Bipolar I disorder with current episode mania
Bipolar II disorder with current episode hypomania

questions.text: A 30-year-old female is overly talkative, hyperactive, doesn’t sleep well and spends a lot of money for shopping for past 2 weeks. When asked questions, she becomes irritable and angry. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bipolar I disorder with current episode mania
• Clinical features mentioned in the question, overtalkativeness, spending more money, for 2 weeks qualifies for diagnosis of mania
• Hypomania is minimum 4 days duration and Mania is diagnosed with minimum 1 week duration of symptoms.
• Irritable and angry mood is also present and 1st episode of mania is diagnosed with bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Borderline tuberculoid leprosy belongs to which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Type IV
Borderline tuberculoid leprosy is a cell-mediated, delayed-type immune response (Type IV hypersensitivity) driven by T cells (Th1) and macrophages targeting Mycobacterium leprae, leading to granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A child presents with raised pink bumps with central umbilications. Identify the causative agent ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Molluscum contagiosum 
The most likely cause is Molluscum contagiosum, a DNA poxvirus infection. It presents as small, raised, dome-shaped pink or skin-colored papules with a central umbilication, commonly on the trunk, face, and limbs of preschool-aged children.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with elevated conjugated bilirubin, clay-colored stools, and dark urine. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Extrahepatic biliary atresia
The most likely diagnosis for a 2-week-old infant with elevated conjugated bilirubin, clay-colored stools, and dark urine is Extrahepatic biliary atresia. This condition is characterized by a blockage in the bile ducts outside the liver, preventing bile from flowing into the intestines and causing elevated conjugated bilirubin, clay-colored stools, and dark urine.

questions.text: In an experimental study involving antigen injection in humans to study immune response, which of the following antibodies appears first after antigen exposure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IgM
IgM is the first antibody produced by the body in response to an antigen exposure, making it the initial responder in the immune system.

questions.text: An elderly woman involved in a road traffic accident presents with progressive shortness of breath and altered level of consciousness. Chest radiography shows findings suggestive of a particular diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fat embolism syndrome
The most likely diagnosis, given the scenario of an elderly woman involved in a road traffic accident presenting with progressive shortness of breath and altered level of consciousness, and chest X-ray findings, is Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES). Fat embolism syndrome can follow trauma such as long-bone fractures, with fat droplets lodging in the lungs, brain, and skin. It presents with acute shortness of breath and hypoxemia, neurological changes (confusion, drowsiness, seizures), a petechial rash on the chest/face/conjunctiva, and chest X-ray showing diffuse bilateral opacities.

questions.text: Most common congenital heart disease in Turner’s syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bicuspid aortic valve disease 
In Turner syndrome, bicuspid aortic valve is the most common congenital heart defect (roughly 30–50%), more frequent than coarctation of the aorta (about 10–15%). Pulmonic stenosis and aortic stenosis are less common in Turner. In Turner's Syndrome, the left side of the heart is affected. The congenital heart diseases present are:
• Bicuspid Aortic Valve disease (most common) 
• Coarctation of Aorta 
• Aortic Stenosis

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with signs of opioid poisoning/overdose. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Naloxone
• Drug of choice for opiod overdose is naloxone, doc for opiod relapse prevention is naltrexone
• Fomepizole is used in methyl alcohol poisoning
• Flumazenil is used in BZD overdose.

questions.text: A woman presents with sudden high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse rash, and a history of using a tampon for an extended period. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Toxic Shock Syndrome
The presentation is Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) from toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus associated with prolonged tampon use. It features sudden high fever, hypotension, and a diffuse, sunburn-like rash that can peel later, making TSS the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is associated with which of the following types of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oropharyngeal cancer
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is strongly associated with cervical cancer, but recent research has shown a significant link between high-risk HPV types and oropharyngeal cancer (cancer of the throat, including the tonsils and base of the tongue).

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer presents with fever, malaise, and diarrhea for 5 days. He reports regular exposure to livestock, including cattle and goats. There is no history of tick or flea bites and no rash on examination. Which organism is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The 38-year-old farmer presenting with fever, malaise, and diarrhea, who has regular exposure to livestock (cattle and goats) and no history of tick or flea bites or a rash, is most likely infected with Coxiella burnetii. 
Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever, typically acquired by farmers via inhalation of contaminated dust or unpasteurized dairy from cattle, sheep, or goats. Acute Q fever often presents with fever, malaise, myalgias, and can include GI symptoms such as nausea and diarrhea; about half of infections are symptomatic. The patient’s farming exposure markedly increases risk, and the lack of a rash helps distinguish it from rickettsial diseases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic. There is no history of fever. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Staphylococcus 
The most likely causative organism for the profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic, with no history of fever, is Staphylococcus. 
The scenario most fits Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin poisoning: very rapid onset (within hours) with prominent vomiting. Clostridium perfringens has a longer onset and less vomiting; Salmonella typically includes fever and longer incubation; Bacillus cereus can mimic vomiting but is usually linked to fried rice or starchy foods and has different food associations. Therefore, Staph aureus is the most likely cause.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with fever, dry cough, and breathlessness. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. His CD4+ T-cell count is 150 cells/mm³. Which of the following organisms ts the most likely cause of pneumonia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pneumocystis jirovecii 
The most likely organism causing pneumonia in this HIV-positive patient with a low CD4+ T-cell count and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray is B. Pneumocystis jirovecii. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a severe opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, especially HIV/AIDS. A CD4 count below 200 cells/mm³ markedly increases risk, with median diagnosis around 50 cells/mm³. A CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³ places the patient in a high-risk category.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with difficulty breathing and is diagnosed with pneumonia. Which is the most common etiologic agent at this age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
The most common etiologic agent for pneumonia in a 3-month-old infant is Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). While other options like Haemophilus influenzae type b and influenza virus can cause pneumonia, RSV is particularly prevalent in young infants, often leading to bronchiolitis and pneumonia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old street food vendor presents with high-grade fever and a biack lesion on his upper back. He reports handling raw goat meat with bare hands 5 days ago. Examination reveals a black eschar with surrounding edema. What is the most likety treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Doxycycline 
The scenario described strongly suggests a case of cutaneous anthrax. This is supported by the patient's occupation (street food vendor handling raw meat), history of handling raw goat meat with bare hands, development of a skin lesion with a characteristic black eschar surrounded by edema, and associated high-grade fever. Doxycycline is a highly effective first-line antibiotic for treating cutaneous anthrax.

questions.text: A patient presents with a wing-shaped (lytic) lesion in a bone. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brodie's abscess
The patient's presentation of a wing-shaped (lytic) lesion in a bone makes Brodie's abscess the most likely condition. Brodie's abscess is a localized area of bone infection (osteomyelitis) that presents as a lytic lesion, often with surrounding reactive sclerosis. Brodie’s abscess classically presents as a well-defined lytic bone lesion with a rim of reactive sclerosis, often showing a wing- or flame-shaped appearance in metaphyseal regions such as the tibia.

questions.text: A child who can smile socially and transfer objects from one hand to the other is also likely to have which of the following milestones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Responds to name
A child is at a developmental age of 7 months if they can transfer an object from one hand to another. At this age, a child can also respond to their name. A child who can smile socially and transfer objects from one hand to the other is most likely to have the milestone of Responding to name.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with enuresis (bedwetting). The paren mention the child had a fall from bed once, but has no other significa medical history. There are no signs of urinary tract infection or neurological deficits. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Behavioral modification 
Enuresis, or bedwetting, is the involuntary release of urine during sleep in children older than five years old. Given this child is 8 years old and has no signs of underlying conditions like UTIs or neurological issues, the first step in management would typically involve behavioral modification.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with a black necrotic lesion near the nasolabial fold. Which is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amphotericin B
In a diabetic patient with a black necrotic lesion near the nasolabial fold, mucormycosis is highly suspected due to its rapid, aggressive tissue destruction and vascular invasion. The infection can quickly spread to adjacent tissues and even the brain.First-line therapy is Amphotericin B, which binds fungal ergosterol to create membrane pores and kill the organism. Early recognition and prompt treatment are critical to improve outcomes.

choices.text: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is being evaluated for short stature. His height is appropriate for age, but his upper-to-lower body segment ratio is 1:1. Bone age is equivalent to 10 years. There is no facial dysmorphism, and both testes are small. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Constitutional delay of growth and puberty
Findings point to constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP): height is age-appropriate, but upper:lower segment ratio is 1:1 with relatively longer legs, delayed bone age by 2 years, and small testes. These support transient growth delay and delayed puberty, with no underlying pathology. Familial short stature usually has normal bone age and normal testes; idiopathic short stature is a diagnosis of exclusion; growth hormone deficiency would show shorter stature and more disproportion.

choices.text: Administer IV bolus of Hartmann solution

questions.text: A newborn, born to a diabetic mother, presents after 24 hours of life with a blood glucose level of <35 mg/dL. The baby is asymptomatic. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Start oral feeds and observe 
In infants of diabetic mothers, monitor for hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia. If asymptomatic hypoglycemia with a capillary blood glucose of 20–44 mg/dL, provide oral feeds.

choices.text: Cleaning the eyes with a wet sterile swab
Placing the baby on the mother’s chest
Initiating breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth

questions.text: A newborn delivered vaginally at a peripheral health centre by ANM. Which of the following actions should not be performed immediately after birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Immediately bathing the baby
Newborns should have immediate skin-to-skin contact, early breastfeeding, and delayed bathing to maintain warmth. Eye cleaning with a wet sterile swab may be done as part of routine care in some settings, and early mother–infant contact is encouraged. Bathing right after birth increases the risk of hypothermia.

questions.text: The following test assesses which ligament of the knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anterior cruciate ligament
Tests like Lachman test and anterior drawer test evaluate ACL integrity. Excessive forward tibial movement indicates ACL tear.
The Lachman test (and the anterior drawer test) assesses ACL integrity by analyzing anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur. A positive Lachman indicates an ACL tear, whereas posterior drawer tests assess the PCL, and tests for MCL or LCL involve valgus/varus stress tests.

questions.text: Identify the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is caused by certain toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus strains that secrete exfoliative toxins ETA and ETB. These serine proteases cleave desmoglein-1 in the upper epidermis, causing loss of cell adhesion and widespread superficial blisters with skin desquamation. Transmission occurs via direct contact or from asymptomatic carriers.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent sinusitis and recurrent chest infections. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the CFTR gene. Which test is the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sweat chloride test
The gold standard to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF) in a patient with recurrent sinusitis, recurrent chest infections, and a CFTR gene mutation is the sweat chloride test.

questions.text: A person presents with a belief that he has lots of property and is rich and somebody he knows wants to kill him and take it from him. This thought sometimes makes him feel sad/depressed. What is the psychopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Delusion of grandeur and Delusion of persecution
• Feeling that I am great/rich is suggestive of delusion of grandiosity
• People are against me and want to harm him is suggestive of delusion of persecution
• The delusion of nihilism is when the person denies the existence, I don’t exist, I am dead, that is not mentioned in this question.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with whitish plaques in the oral cavity. A KOH preparation shows budding yeast with pseudohyphae. Which is the most appropriate culture medium to isolate this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA)
The most appropriate culture medium to isolate the organism described (budding yeast with pseudohyphae from oral plaques in a diabetic patient, suggestive of Candida infection) is B. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA).

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with a fracture as shown. Which type of fracture is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intertrochanteric fracture
In a road traffic accident with a fracture as shown in X-ray is an intertrochanteric fracture (between the greater and lesser trochanters) is the most likely in a high‑energy injury. Subtrochanteric fractures just distal to the lesser trochanter are possible but less common, femoral neck fractures are more typical of elderly falls, and pubic rami fractures are pelvic and often treated nonoperatively.

questions.text: A woman was bitten by a rabid dog. The dog develops symptoms and dies within a week. Which is the best method for antemortem diagnosis of rabies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DFAT
DFAT (Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test) is the gold standard for confirming rabies, but it is most reliably performed on brain tissue after death. For antemortem diagnosis in a person exposed to a rabid animal, clinicians typically use methods such as RT-PCR on saliva, CSF, or serum, and may obtain corneal impression smears or skin biopsies when available. DFAT on corneal or salivary specimens can be used antemortem, but Negri bodies identified by brain biopsy (via seller stain) are classic postmortem findings.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and sore throat. A throat swab cultured on chocolate agar shows Gram-negative coccobacilli. Which organism is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haemophilus influenzae
The child's symptoms (fever and sore throat), along with the microbiology findings (Gram-negative coccobacilli cultured on chocolate agar), strongly suggest Haemophilus influenzae. Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that specifically requires enriched media like chocolate agar for growth, as it needs factors V (NAD+) and X (hemin) released from lysed red blood cells. It is a known cause of respiratory tract infections, including pharyngitis, especially in children.
Listeria monocytogenes: Is a Gram-positive rod.
Streptococcus pneumoniae: Is a Gram-positive coccus.
Escherichia coli: Is a Gram-negative rod.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pain and gas bubbles (crepitus) in soft tissue. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

C. histolyticum
Gas-forming soft-tissue infection (gas gangrene) is due to Clostridium species; among the options, C. histolyticum is the most plausible causative agent associated with clostridial tissue destruction and gas production.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, when started on antipsychotic agent developed muscular dystonia and was treated for it. Patient presents with complaints of dry mouth, dizziness and hypotension. What is the most likely drug causing these side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Benztropine
Benztropine is centrally acting anticholinergic agent, that is used to treat antipsychotic induced dystonia (extra pyramidal side effects). It can cause anticholinergic side effects like dry mouth, dizziness and hypotension.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with bedwetting twice a week, there was one episode of falling from bed. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Behavioural Therapy
• Best treatment of nocturnal enuresis is “bell and pad” classical conditioning, which is a type of behavioural therapy, hence the best answer is behavioural therapy.
• Desmopressin is the drug of choice and not the treatment of choice.
• Cognitive behavioural therapy has no much role here

questions.text: Identify the virus shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Influenza virus 
Influenza viruses are characterized by their segmented, negative-sense RNA genome and spiked surface proteins like hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA), which are visible in the image.

questions.text: Which culture medium is used for Sporothrix schenckii?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sabouraud dextrose agar
Sporothrix schenckii is routinely cultured on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA). Niger seed and Bird seed agars are used for Cryptococcus species (to assess melanin production), and Ashdown agar is used for Burkholderia pseudomallei.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with fast breathing (respiratory rate 58/min), chest indrawing, nasal flaring, and poor feeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Severe pneumonia
The most likely diagnosis for a 4-month-old infant with fast breathing, chest indrawing, nasal flaring, and poor feeding is Severe pneumonia.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for treating brucellosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Doxycycline plus rifampin
For adults with uncomplicated brucellosis, the WHO recommends combination therapy with doxycycline and either rifampin or streptomycin. However, due to concerns about high relapse rates with monotherapy, combination therapy is the preferred and widely accepted approach.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain and redness in the eyes, she wears contact lens and admits to maintaining poor lens hygiene. Which of the following is most likely causative organism involved in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acanthamoeba
Acanthamoeba is the most likely causative organism in this scenario, given the patient's contact lens wear and poor hygiene, which significantly increases the risk of infection with this parasite; pain and redness in the eyes are common symptoms associated with Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with diarrhea. Stool microscopy reveals oocysts measuring 11 microns. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cyclospora 
Based on 11 µm oocysts in stool from an HIV-positive patient with diarrhea, the most likely organism is Cyclospora cayetanensis. Cyclospora oocysts are about 8–11 µm; other parasites have notably different sizes (Cryptosporidium 4–6 µm, Cyclospora fits best, Giardia cysts 8–19 µm but are not classified as oocysts).

questions.text: A female reports that a man came walking from 100 kms away from a near by village to her place. The man is unable to remember his name and has no memory about coming there. Likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dissociative fugue
• History of travel, reaching a new place and forgetting about his identity is suggestive of diagnosis of dissociative fugue.
• In dissociative amnesia, there is only loss of memory, no travel history would be there.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a fracture of the femoral neck. Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal fixation 
In young adults, internal fixation is generally preferred to preserve the femoral head. However, if the patient is elderly or the fracture is displaced, hemiarthroplasty is favored to avoid complications like avascular necrosis or non-union.

questions.text: A girl came with history of schizophrenia to a PHC. Which of the following is the Tele Mental health program provided by government of India to deliver mental health care services via telephone and online application?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Telemanas
Tele-MANAS is an initiative of the Indian Ministry of Health & Family Welfare that stands for Tele Mental Health Assistance and Networking Across States. 
It's a nationwide, 24/7, toll-free helpline (14416) providing free tele-mental health services. The program aims to offer mental health support, especially to those in remote or underserved areas, and to bridge the gap in mental healthcare accessibility

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, and maculopapular rash. Torniquet test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dengue fever
The patient's symptoms of high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, maculopapular rash, and positive tourniquet test are highly suggestive of Dengue fever. Dengue fever is characterized by these clinical features, including fever, headache (often retro-orbital), muscle and joint pain, and a rash. A positive tourniquet test, indicating easy bruising due to capillary fragility, is also commonly seen in dengue.

questions.text: A patient with acute rheumatic fever presenting with migratory polyarthritis. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

High-dose aspirin
In acute rheumatic fever with arthritis alone, the best treatment is giving aspirin alone. Corticosteroids are given if carditis is present.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with vesicular lesions over the lips and oral mucosa. A Tzanck smear prepared from the lesion reveals multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Herpes simplex virus
The likely agent is Herpes simplex virus (HSV). Classic vesicles on the lips/oral mucosa diagnose HSV infection. A Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells supports herpes infections; HSV promotes cell fusion (syncytia) leading to these giant cells.

questions.text: Which opportunistic pathogen shows a crushed ping-pong ball appearance on Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pneumocystis jirovecii
Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus causing Pneumocystis pneumonia in immunocompromised patients. On Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining, its cysts appear as collapsed, “crushed” ping-pong ball–like structures (crescent-shaped), aiding diagnosis in lung tissue or bronchoalveolar lavage.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sore throat and low-grade fever. On physical examination, multiple vesicular lesions are noted on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coxsackievirus A16 
HFMD is the likely diagnosis in a 4-year-old with sore throat, low-grade fever, and vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa. It is typically caused by Coxsackievirus A16, with a 3–7 day incubation. Symptoms include mouth ulcers, fever, and a non-itchy, painful rash on the palms and soles. Complications can include dehydration and rarely meningitis or encephalitis. Transmission occurs via close contact with respiratory secretions, blister fluid, or stool.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child presents with head dropping and brief spasms of the neck and trunk. EEG shows a hypsarrhythmic pattern. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ACTH
The 6-month-old child presenting with head dropping, brief spasms of the neck and trunk, and a hypsarrhythmic EEG pattern likely has Infantile Spasms (also known as West Syndrome). The treatment of choice for this condition is often considered to be Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH). The features given are suggestive of Infantile spasm. There is a triad of:
• Neurodevelopmental regression
• Spasm (<2>• Hypsarrhythmic pattern on EEG

The drug of choice is ACTH.

questions.text: A Tzanck smear from lesions shows multinucleated giant cells. Which pathogen is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Herpes simplex virus 
The most likely pathogens responsible for multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear are Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and Herpes simplex virus (HSV). A Tzanck smear is a rapid and inexpensive test used in dermatology to examine cells from the base of skin lesions, particularly blisters or ulcers. The presence of multinucleated giant cells (large cells with multiple nuclei) in the smear is a characteristic finding in certain viral infections.

questions.text: Which defect is characteristic of Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Deficiency of GPIb receptors
Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare bleeding disorder primarily characterized by a deficiency of the platelet glycoprotein Ib (GPIb) complex, which is crucial for binding to von Willebrand factor (VWF) on the endothelial lining of blood vessels, leading to impaired platelet adhesion and aggregation.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the oral lesions seen in Kaposi sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Purple-red, elevated lesions
Kaposi sarcoma oral lesions are typically violaceous and raised. They often begin as flat red patches that progress to darker, purple-red nodules or plaques, with the characteristic color helping distinguish them from flat lesions.

choices.text: Point B to Point D represents Absolute refractory period
Point C to Point E represents refractory period
Point C to Point D is mediated by Na influx

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the graph given:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Point B to Point D represents Absolute refractory period
A. Point A represents Threshold Potential
• Point A represents the resting membrane potential (~ -70 mV).
• Threshold potential is marked by Point E (~ -55 mV).
B. Point B to Point D represents Absolute refractory period
• Absolute refractory period occurs from beginning of depolarization B to half of hyperpolarization when Na⁺ channels are either open or inactivated.
• Point D is beyond this; at D, the relative refractory period is ongoing.
C. Point C to Point E represents refractory period
• Point C is peak/repolarization, and Point E is threshold potential (which occurs earlier).
• The refractory period doesn’t match this range; this statement is anatomically inconsistent.
D. Point C to Point D is mediated by Na⁺ influx
• Point C to D is repolarization and hyperpolarization, mainly mediated by K⁺ efflux, not Na⁺ influx.

questions.text: In the ICU, after a failed subclavian catheterization attempt, the patient experiences a sudden drop in blood pressure with a rapid pulse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumothorax
The most likely diagnosis in a patient who experiences a sudden drop in blood pressure with a rapid pulse after a failed subclavian catheterization attempt in the ICU is Pneumothorax. 
Subclavian catheterization has a notable risk of pneumothorax because the subclavian vein sits near the lung. Pneumothorax causes air in the pleural space, lung collapse, and impaired respiration with reduced venous return, potentially leading to hypotension and tachycardia. Air embolism is possible but pneumothorax is the more common immediate complication and can be worsened by positive-pressure ventilation.

questions.text: A patient with head trauma is conscious but answers questions with fluent speech that are irrelevant to the questions. Which brain area is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superior temporal gyrus
Fluent but nonsensical speech with poor comprehension indicates Wernicke’s aphasia, due to damage of the left superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke’s area, area 22) in the dominant hemisphere.
• Precentral gyrus: primary motor cortex; lesions cause motor deficits, not language comprehension.
• Inferior frontal gyrus: Broca’s area; lesions cause non-fluent, effortful speech with relatively preserved comprehension.
• Basal ganglia: movement disorders; not a primary language area.

questions.text: A young man has the following hepatitis B serology: HBsAg positive, IgM anti-HBc negative, IgG anti-HBc positive, and HBeAg positive. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lamivudine
The most appropriate treatment for a young man with the given hepatitis B serology (HBsAg positive, IgM anti-HBc negative, IgG anti-HBc positive, and HBeAg positive) is Lamivudine.
For chronic hepatitis B with active replication (HBeAg-positive), antiviral therapy is indicated using nucleos(t)ide analogs such as lamivudine or tenofovir. Ombitasvir is used for chronic hepatitis C, not hepatitis B. Ritonavir and abacavir are antiretroviral drugs used in HIV management, not HBV infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight gain, thinning hair, and dry skin. With a diagnosis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which antibody is typically detected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anti-TPO antibodies
The patient's symptoms of weight gain, thinning hair, and dry skin are consistent with hypothyroidism, which is commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Anti-TPO antibodies are present in over 90% of individuals with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and play a key role in the pathogenesis of the disease by damaging the thyroid gland.
While anti-thyroglobulin (TgAb) antibodies are also associated with Hashimoto's, their prevalence is lower (50-80% of patients). Anti-TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb) are primarily associated with Graves' disease, causing hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has persistent hypercalcemia for 1.5 years with normal parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Malignancy
Given the persistent hypercalcemia with normal PTH levels, the most likely cause is Malignancy. Can often cause hypercalcemia due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrp) by tumor cells, which mimics the action of PTH and leads to elevated calcium levels even with normal PTH levels. 
Hypercalcemia with a normal or low PTH points to a non–PTH–mediated cause, such as malignancy.
In sarcoidosis, granulomas increase production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to hypercalcemia with suppressed PTH. In contrast, parathyroid hyperplasia and chronic kidney disease usually cause elevated PTH levels, not normal ones.

choices.text: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome treated with systemic antibiotics

questions.text: Identify the condition and its appropriate treatment:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome treated with systemic antibiotics
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is caused by S. aureus producing toxins and is primarily treated with systemic antibiotics to eradicate the toxin-producing infection. In contrast, Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) is managed mainly with protective dressings and supportive care to prevent trauma, since it is a genetic blistering disorder. Impetigo is typically treated with topical or oral antibiotics targeting the superficial bacterial infection. Erythema Multiforme is a hypersensitivity reaction usually managed by treating the underlying trigger and providing supportive care for symptoms such as fever and rash.

questions.text: A child with progressive pallor has hemolysis and an elevated HbS on HPLC. Which is the best treatment to reduce hemolysis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hydroxyurea
A child with progressive pallor and elevated HbS, a hallmark of sickle cell disease (SCD). Hydroxyurea is the most established and widely used medication for managing SCD. Hydroxyurea works by increasing the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which can inhibit the polymerization of HbS and prevent sickling of red blood cells (RBCs). By reducing sickling, hydroxyurea can decrease hemolysis and its associated complications, including anemia, pain crises, and organ damage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain consistent with a cluster headache. What is the best initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oxygen
Oxygen High-flow oxygen is a first-line acute treatment for cluster headaches. It is administered at a high flow rate (typically 12-15 L/min) via a non-rebreather mask for a short duration (15-20 minutes) and is generally effective and well-tolerated. While the exact mechanism is not fully understood, it is believed to involve vasoconstriction and modulation of the trigeminovascular system. Oxygen therapy can provide relief within minutes for many patients with cluster headaches.

choices.text: Sodium channel abnormality causing excessive muscle activation
Increased release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal myocytes
Decreased ATP binding with myosin head

questions.text: Subject is diagnosed with Ryanodine receptor mutation. What is the likely abnormality that can happen with this pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal myocytes
RyR1 mutations cause malignant hyperthermia by causing excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, triggering strong contractions and hyperthermia.

choices.text: Thickened posterior auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 1
Thickened greater auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 1
Thickened posterior auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 2
Thickened greater auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 2

questions.text: Which statement best describes the finding shown in the image (a close-up of the neck/ear area with an arrow)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thickened greater auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 1
The finding shown in the image is consistent with Thickened greater auricular nerve with leprosy reaction type 1.

questions.text: A patient presents with increased arm span, hypermobile joints, and lens subluxation (ectopia lentis). Which protein is defective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fibrillin-1
Marfan syndrome is caused by a defect in the gene that codes for Fibrillin-1. Mutations in the FBN1 gene, which produces fibrillin-1, disrupt the formation and function of elastic fibers, leading to the varied symptoms observed in Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A patient who has had a recent myocardial infarction develops a broad-complex tachycardia. Blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. An ECG is provided. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intravenous amiodarone
A patient who has recently experienced a myocardial infarction and subsequently develops a broad-complex tachycardia, while remaining hemodynamically stable (blood pressure 120/85 mmHg), should be considered for intravenous amiodarone.  Broad QRS tachycardia with Regular HR favours Ventricular tachycardia. Since BP is normal, the first line treatment is IV Amiodarone. In presence of Shock, the best would have been DC Cardioversion.

choices.text: A fibres are more susceptible to pressure, followed by B fibres & C fibres equally
Pain in this condition is carried by A delta fibres.
Pain in this condition is carried by C fibres
All the nerve fibres got affected because of this pressure and that is the reason for pain.

questions.text: A subject sleeps with arm under his head. Upon waking, he notices tingling sensation and pain in his arm. Identify the correct statement regarding this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A fibres are more susceptible to pressure, followed by B fibres & C fibres equally
Nerve fibers show different sensitivity to pressure. Large myelinated A fibers are the most susceptible to compression, while smaller myelinated B fibers and unmyelinated C fibers are comparatively more resistant. This pattern explains why prolonged external pressure, such as keeping an arm under the head during sleep, first produces paresthesias mediated by A-fiber pathways (A-beta and A-alpha conduction blocks).
Regarding pain fibers, A-delta fibers are myelinated, fast, and produce sharp, well-localized pain, whereas C fibers are unmyelinated and convey slower, dull, aching pain. Clinically, under compression, conduction block of the large myelinated fibers leads to tingling or paresthesia, whereas any pain experienced is more likely to be carried by C fibers (dull) or, for sharp pain, by A-delta fibers.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension has a renal mass identified on imaging and an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adrenalectomy
The next best step in management for a patient with hypertension, a renal mass, and an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) is Adrenalectomy. An elevated ARR strongly suggests the presence of primary aldosteronism, a condition where the adrenal glands produce too much aldosterone, leading to high blood pressure. Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis favours Aldosterone excess states.
Hypertension favours primary hyperalsosteronism. With mass over the kidney, the diagnosis is likely to be Conn’s syndrome which can be cured by adrenalectomy.

questions.text: Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows abundant neutrophils with low glucose and elevated protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute bacterial meningitis (ABM)
The most likely diagnosis for cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing abundant neutrophils with low glucose and elevated protein is Acute bacterial meningitis (ABM).

questions.text: A patient presents with cough and weight loss. Biopsy of a lung mass shows expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which paraneoplastic syndrome is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

SIADH
The biopsy results indicating expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin suggest a neuroendocrine tumor of the lung. Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that often expresses these markers. Paraneoplastic syndromes are a group of disorders caused by substances secreted by tumor cells that are unrelated to the tumor's direct invasion or metastasis. 
Among the given options, the paraneoplastic syndrome most likely associated with SCLC is SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion). This is because SCLC cells have the capacity to ectopically produce ADH, leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys and consequent hyponatremia.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and altered mental status. Peripheral blood smear shows multiple ring-stage parasites. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Artesunate
The patient presents with altered mental status, indicating severe malaria. Severe malaria is a medical emergency and requires prompt, aggressive treatment. Intravenous artesunate is recommended as the first-line treatment for severe malaria, regardless of the infecting species. Artesunate has been shown to reduce mortality more effectively than quinine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with headache and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT (NCCT) head image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Sudden onset headache and neck stiffness are classic symptoms of SAH. The blood in the subarachnoid space irritates the meninges (the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord), causing these symptoms. On NCCT, SAH appears as hyperdense (bright white) blood in the subarachnoid space, which outlines the sulci and cisterns of the brain.

questions.text: A patient with Road Traffic Accident (RTA) has received four units of packed red blood cells within a few hours. Which electrolyte disturbance is likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Hypocalcemia 
Packed red blood cells (pRBCs), like most blood products, are stored with a citrate-containing solution to prevent clotting. When large amounts of blood are transfused quickly (as in this case with four units in a few hours), the liver's capacity to metabolize this citrate can be overwhelmed.

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations, headaches, and sweating. Blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, and 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pheochromocytoma
The most likely diagnosis, given the symptoms of palpitations, headaches, sweating, high blood pressure (180/100 mmHg), and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines, is Pheochromocytoma. This is a rare tumor, usually benign, that develops in the adrenal glands and releases excessive amounts of hormones called catecholamines (adrenaline and noradrenaline). These hormones can cause symptoms like those described: high blood pressure, headaches, sweating, and palpitations. The elevated levels of metanephrines (breakdown products of catecholamines) in the 24-hour urine test are a key diagnostic indicator for pheochromocytoma. 
Carcinoid tumor releases serotonin (and 5-HIAA); causes flushing, diarrhea, sometimes palpitations, but not elevated metanephrines.
Carcinoid crisis is life-threatening carcinoid syndrome flare (flushing, hypotension, bronchospasm, confusion) triggered by stress or surgery; metanephrine elevation is not typical.
Neuroblastoma is pediatric cancer that can raise catecholamines and blood pressure; however, the presentation with high metanephrines favors pheochromocytoma over neuroblastoma.

choices.text: Chill cold weather & Airway hypersensitivity - Bronchoconstriction

questions.text: While exercising in cold weather, a person develops dyspnea. Which statement best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chill cold weather & Airway hypersensitivity - Bronchoconstriction
Exposure to cold air can trigger airway hyperresponsiveness and bronchoconstriction, especially in people with asthma. Although the sympathetic system typically promotes bronchodilation, its effect is often overridden by the cold-induced response. The parasympathetic system can cause bronchoconstriction, but in cold-induced dyspnea the primary driver is the cold air itself rather than parasympathetic activity.

questions.text: A patient presents with contralateral weakness of the face, arm, and leg. Non-contrast CT head reveals intracerebral hemorrhage. Where is the most likely location of the bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Basal ganglia
Contralateral weakness affecting the face, arm, and leg, along with an intracerebral hemorrhage identified on a non-contrast CT head, most likely indicates a bleed in the internal capsule, a component of the basal ganglia.  The most common location for intracerebral hemorrhage is the basal ganglia. If a patient presents with pinpoint pupils, the hemorrhage is more likely pontine in origin.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a history of rheumatic fever presents with a loud S1 and a mid-diastolic murmur. Which valvular heart disease is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitral stenosis (MS)
The most likely diagnosis for a 25-year-old female with a history of rheumatic fever presenting with a loud S1 and a mid-diastolic murmur is Mitral stenosis (MS). 
Rheumatic fever is the most common cause of mitral stenosis. Damage from rheumatic fever can lead to thickening and fusion of the mitral valve leaflets, hindering proper opening and causing stenosis (narrowing). Symptoms of mitral stenosis may not appear for years or even decades after the initial rheumatic fever episode. A loud S1 (first heart sound), often described as palpable, is a characteristic finding in mitral stenosis. This is because the thickened and stiff mitral valve closes with increased force when the pressure in the left ventricle rises at the beginning of systole.

questions.text: A HIV-positive patient presents with chronic diarrhea for four weeks. Stool microscopy shows oval/elliptical cysts measuring about 16 × 20 μm. What is the most likely etiologic organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystoisospora belli
The most likely etiologic organism in an HIV-positive patient with chronic diarrhea and oval/elliptical cysts measuring about 16 x 20 µm in stool microscopy is D. Cystoisospora belli (formerly known as Isospora belli).

Cystoisospora belli causes large oval cysts and chronic diarrhea in HIV.
Cryptosporidium — Smaller cysts (4-6 µm); acid-fast.
Cryptococcus — Causes meningitis, not diarrhea.
Cyclospora — Smaller cysts (8-10 µm).

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with multiple small, skin-colored papules on the trunk and face, each with a central umbilication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Molluscum contagiosum
Molluscum contagiosum virus causes characteristic skin lesions consisting of single or, more often, multiple, rounded, dome-shaped, pink, waxy papules that are 2-5 mm (rarely up to 1.5 cm in the case of a giant molluscum) in diameter. The papules, or bumps, are umbilicated and contain a caseous plug.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident develops acute kidney injury. Laboratory workup shows a fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) < 1% and a urine osmolality of 500 mOsm/L. What is the most likely type of AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prerenal AKI
The most likely type of AKI in a patient with a fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) < 1>

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated, and MRI reveals a pituitary adenoma. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bromocriptine
The patient's symptoms (amenorrhea and galactorrhea) along with elevated prolactin levels and a pituitary adenoma strongly suggest a prolactinoma. 
A prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma) is best treated initially with a dopamine agonist to suppress prolactin secretion and shrink the tumor; bromocriptine (often cabergoline as another option) is first-line, whereas letrozole, tamoxifen, or goserelin are not appropriate for managing a prolactinoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive limb weakness for the past year. Exam reveals muscle fasciculations and hypertonia, with preserved sensation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
The presentation of progressive limb weakness, muscle fasciculations (muscle twitches), and hypertonia (increased muscle tone), along with preserved sensation, strongly suggests ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. ALS is a neurodegenerative disease that affects both upper and lower motor neurons, leading to progressive muscle weakness and paralysis.  While most cases are sporadic, around 10% of ALS cases have a genetic component, with over 40 genes now linked to the disease. These genes, such as SOD1, C9orf72, TARDBP, and FUS, play roles in motor neuron function and are implicated in the disease's development. 
B. Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is early-onset via lower motor neuron degeneration; prominent muscle atrophy rather than hypertonia, and it mainly affects LMNs (not the UMN involvement seen in ALS).
C. Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) is rare, focal, asymmetrical motor nerve disease causing weakness, cramps, and fasciculations; gradual onset and cramping/spasms are common, with less hypertonia and widespread involvement unlike ALS.
D. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is genetic progressive muscle weakness, mainly in hips/thighs with waddling gait; onset earlier than described, no upper motor neuron signs, and weakness/atrophy without ALS-like hypertonia or fasciculations.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with dark red urine due to myoglobinuria. Which electrolyte disturbance is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperkalemia
When a patient presents with myoglobinuria due to a road traffic accident, the most likely electrolyte disturbance to be observed is Hyperkalemia.

choices.text: She is hypoventilating; and that makes her dyspneic.
Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is lesser than that in Delhi and that makes her hemoglobin to decrease O2 delivery to tissues; causing dyspnoea.
She is hyperventilating, causing dyspnoea and Respiratory Alkalosis
Atmospheric Oxygen in Leh is higher than that in Delhi and that makes her to experience dyspnoea.

questions.text: A 28 year old woman arrives Leh Airport form Delhi. Upon Arrival, she experienced dyspnoea. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

She is hyperventilating, causing dyspnoea and Respiratory Alkalosis
At high altitude, hypoxemia triggers reflex hyperventilation, causing low PaCO2 and acute respiratory alkalosis. Hyperventilation itself contributes to dyspnea, which may improve with acclimatization as renal compensation gradually reduces alkalosis.

choices.text: Demyelination of peripheral nerves affecting both A- and B-fibers

questions.text: A patient presents with symmetric weakness of the legs and areflexia, following diarrheal illness two weeks earlier. The diagnosis is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). What is the primary pathological process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Demyelination of peripheral nerves affecting both A- and B-fibers
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is primarily characterized by an autoimmune response that damages the myelin sheaths surrounding peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination of both sensory and motor nerve fibers (A- and B-fibers). This damage results in the characteristic muscle weakness, decreased reflexes (areflexia), and sensory abnormalities that are typical of GBS.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair of hormones responsible for growth of the marked structures:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Estrogen stimulates growth and branching of the (A) ductal system in the breast and also increases deposition of fat and stromal tissue. Progesterone, on the other hand, promotes development of the alveoli and (B) lobules and prepares the glandular tissue for milk secretion.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive shortness of breath for six months and a dry cough. On examination, there are bilateral basal inspiratory crackles. There is no fever, joint pain, or occupational exposure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)
The patient’s progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and bilateral basal fine inspiratory crackles (“Velcro” crackles) are highly suggestive of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The lack of fever, joint symptoms, or known occupational exposure helps exclude infectious, autoimmune, and exposure-related ILDs. End-inspiratory crepitations are typical of interstitial lung disease. Although ILDs can arise from occupational exposure, autoimmune disease, or drugs, the absence of these factors makes IPF the most likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Reduced production of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and prostacyclin
Reduced production of PGE1 and prostacyclin
Mucosal injury due to selective inhibition of COX-2

questions.text: A patient with osteoarthritis has been taking ibuprofen for the past 3 months and now develops occult gastrointestinal bleeding. Which statement best explains the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Reduced production of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and prostacyclin
NSAIDs (like Ibuprofen) inhibit COX enzymes: Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes. COX-1, one of the two main COX enzymes, produces prostaglandins like PGE2 and prostacyclin, which play a crucial role in protecting the gastric mucosa. Ibuprofen, by inhibiting COX-1, reduces the production of these protective prostaglandins, making the stomach lining more vulnerable to damage from gastric acid and other aggressors.

choices.text: Subendocardial ischemia due to increased demand of myocardium
Increased sympathomimetic drive in morning hours

questions.text: A female patient complaints of chest pain while waking up in morning. Pain is more in winter months. Which of the following best describes this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ach-induced coronary vasoconstriction 
Ach-induced coronary vasoconstriction refers to a condition where the coronary arteries constrict due to the increased activity of acetylcholine (Ach), a neurotransmitter. This constriction can lead to reduced blood flow to the heart muscle, causing chest pain, particularly during the morning when the body is experiencing a heightened state of sympathetic nervous system activation (which can trigger Ach release).

questions.text: A dentist presents with painful vesicular lesions on the hands and a fever for the past week. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Herpes simplex virus 1
Most likely diagnosis: Herpetic whitlow (HSV-1). Healthcare workers like dentists are exposed to the virus via saliva or contact with active lesions, and infection presents as painful vesicles on a finger, often with fever. Paronychia is a bacterial infection around the nailfold and usually lacks clear vesicles with fever; herpes zoster would typically show a unilateral dermatomal rash; candidiasis tends to cause moist, itchy rashes rather than painful finger vesicles.

questions.text: Infant is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of seizures. ECG shows Hypsarrhythmia. Which drug is preferred for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ACTH 
An infant being evaluated for recurrent seizures and showing hypsarrhythmia on ECG likely has infantile spasms, a type of epileptic encephalopathy. The preferred initial treatments for infantile spasms with hypsarrhythmia are ACTH and vigabatrin.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with central chest pain. He has a prior history of heart disease. An ECG is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anterolateral myocardial infarction
Based on the description of central chest pain in a patient with a history of heart disease, and the provided ECG showing ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V3-V6, the most likely diagnosis is an anterolateral myocardial infarction.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with palpitations, dizziness, and episodes of syncope. On examination, the pulse is irregularly irregular. What would you expect to find on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Absent a waves
The patient's presentation with palpitations, dizziness, syncope, and an irregularly irregular pulse suggests the presence of an irregular heart rhythm, such as atrial fibrillation. In atrial fibrillation, the atria (upper chambers of the heart) do not contract in a coordinated manner; instead, they quiver irregularly. This means there's no synchronized atrial contraction to produce the 'a' wave in the JVP, which represents atrial systole (contraction).

questions.text: A patient with known hyperthyroidism, who is not on antithyroid treatment, is scheduled for total thyroidectomy. Preoperative evaluation was not properly completed. What is the most likely intraoperative complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arrhythmia
Improper control of hyperthyroidism pre-operatively can lead to thyroid storm leading to risk of tachyarrythmias.

questions.text: A pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm produces which visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bitemporal hemianopia
When a pituitary adenoma grows and compresses the optic chiasm, the most common visual field defect produced is bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA. NCCT head was normal. Patient died after few days of ICU admission for coma and brain biopsy of brain shows multiple punctuate haemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diffuse Axonal injury 
The correct diagnosis for a patient with a history of RTA, normal initial NCCT head scan, subsequent coma, and brain biopsy revealing multiple punctate hemorrhages is likely Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI).

choices.text: Bedside chest X-ray in casualty followed by chest tube insertion
Immediate insertion of a wide-bore needle into the second intercostal space

questions.text: A patient presents with distended neck veins, absent breath sounds on one side, hyperresonance, and tracheal deviation. What is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Immediate insertion of a wide-bore needle into the second intercostal space
The immediate management for a patient presenting with distended neck veins, absent breath sounds on one side, hyperresonance, and tracheal deviation is immediate insertion of a wide-bore needle into the second intercostal space. Signs described are classic for a tension pneumothorax, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate decompression. Inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side to release the trapped air is the first step in management.

choices.text: Presynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ
Postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ
Voltage-gated calcium channels at the NMJ

questions.text: A young woman presents with ptosis that varies during the day. CT chest reveals an anterior mediastinal mass identified as a thymic tumor. Which receptor is affected at the neuromuscular junction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ
The patient's fluctuating ptosis and the presence of a thymic tumor strongly suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis (MG). Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies attack the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, reducing acetylcholine binding and impairing nerve-to-muscle transmission. This causes muscle weakness and fatigability, especially with use, evident as fluctuating ptosis. Thymomas are linked to MG in about 10–15% of cases, suggesting a role for the thymus in autoantibody production.
Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS): This disorder affects the presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, impairing the release of acetylcholine.

questions.text: A child diagnosed with Kawasaki disease has multiple coronary artery aneurysms. Which antiplatelet treatment regimen is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aspirin plus clopidogrel for 6 weeks
For a child with Kawasaki disease and multiple coronary artery aneurysms, the preferred antiplatelet regimen is aspirin combined with clopidogrel for about 6 weeks. Although low-dose aspirin alone is used after the acute phase, the presence of coronary artery aneurysms (CAAs) raises thrombosis risk, so adding clopidogrel enhances antiplatelet protection. This dual therapy is typically maintained for six weeks.

questions.text: As neuron diameter increases, which statement best describes the effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Conduction velocity increases
Larger diameter reduces axial (internal) resistance, allowing faster current spread. This accelerates propagation, increasing conduction velocity. 
Membrane resistance per unit length actually decreases with larger diameter (more surface area for leakage).Action potential amplitude remains unchanged (still an all-or-none event).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) safe according to MEC1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HIV infection

MEC 1 means no restriction for OCPs. Well-controlled HIV infection is generally MEC 1 (safe). Diabetes mellitus, uncontrolled hypertension, and hyperlipidemia typically carry higher MEC categories (e.g., MEC 2–3 depending on severity and vascular disease), so they are not universally MEC 1 safe options.

Conditions like uncontrolled diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension are typically considered restrictions or contraindications (MEC 3 or 4) for OCPs.

Hyperlipidemia is also a condition where OCPs are generally not the preferred or recommended agent.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic sign being shown in image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Hegar sign
Hegar's sign (image) Softening and compressibility of the lower uterine segment (cervical isthmus) with a firmer uterine body, detected on a bimanual pelvic exam. It appears in early pregnancy (roughly 4–12 weeks). On examination, the clinician notes a softer, more pliable lower uterus while the upper body remains firm. Assessed during a bimanual exam with one hand on the abdomen and the other in the vagina.

questions.text: A patient presented with complain of passage of dark coloured stools for the last few days. He has been suffering from epigastric pain for quite some time for which he has been taking PPI’s often. He was diagnosed with a duodenal polyp on investigations. Which of the following is likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gastrin
This patient is most likely to have elevated gastrin. The combination of long-term PPI use, epigastric pain, dark stools, and a duodenal polyp suggests the presence of a gastrin-secreting tumor, also known as a gastrinoma.

questions.text: A woman sustains a perineal tear during delivery. Examination reveals that less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is involved. Based on the classification system, what is the most appropriate description of this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Grade 3a

The most appropriate description for a perineal tear involving less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is Grade 3a.

questions.text: What does a linear accelerator (LINAC) produce in radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 X-rays and electrons 
A linear accelerator (LINAC) in radiation therapy produces high-energy X-rays (photons) and electrons. It accelerates electrons to high speeds, which can be directed to produce X-ray beams for deep-seated tumors or used directly as electron beams for treating superficial cancers. LINACs are versatile devices widely used in cancer treatment for their ability to deliver precise and targeted radiation doses.

questions.text: A patient presented with hemetemesis most likely due to esophageal variceal bleed. Which of the following should be the next best step in the manangement of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Endoscopic variceal ligation 
Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is the preferred initial management for an active esophageal variceal bleed, as it more effectively stops bleeding and prevents rebleeding compared with endoscopic sclerotherapy (EST). Beta-blockers like labetalol are useful for preventing first or recurrent bleeds in stable patients but are not the first-line treatment for an active bleed. Shunt surgery is reserved for selected patients with severe liver disease and recurrent bleeding who are not candidates for endoscopic therapy.

choices.text: Postpartum hemorrhage due to retained placenta

questions.text: A woman has delivered she develops pain hypotension and tachycardia, shock is out of proprotin due to bleeding. Examination reveal large boggy mass at introitus as shown, what is diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Uterine inversion
Uterine inversion presents with acute severe pain, shock, tachycardia, a large boggy mass with the red mucosal uterine surface protruding and no visible external os. The shock is primarily hemorrhagic/hypovolemic, though early neurogenic shock may occur. Immediate management is Johnson’s manual repositioning in the labor room; do not delay for surgery. If the placenta is still attached, it should be repositioned with the uterus and oxytocin given to promote natural placental expulsion, as pulling the placenta can cause re-inversion. By contrast, uterine prolapse typically shows an external os and does not present with such life-threatening acute shock.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has been raised as a girl, has not developed breast tissue, and ultrasound reveals absence of the uterus. Karyotyping shows a 46,XY chromosomal pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

17-hydroxylase deficiency
17-hydroxylase deficiency  aligns with the description of primary amenorrhea, absent breast tissue, absent uterus, and a 46, XY karyotype. Gonadectomy is not performed. This specific enzyme deficiency is known to cause abnormal sexual development primarily in 46, XY (male) individuals, rather than 46, XX (female). In 46, XX females, the most common enzyme deficiencies causing abnormal sexual development are 21-hydroxylase (associated with hyponatremia and hypotension) and 11-hydroxylase (associated with hypertension).

questions.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are protective against all of the following cancers except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Cervical cancer 
OCPs are known to reduce the risk of:
• Endometrial cancer
• Colorectal cancer
• Ovarian cancer
• Reduction in blood loss, helping to regulate cycles (beneficial for women with PCOS)
• Decreased pain (useful in dysmenorrhea or endometriosis)
• Reduced fibroids (due to decreased blood loss)
• Reduced formation of ovarian cysts
• Lower incidence of benign breast disease
Conversely, OCPs are associated with an increased risk of:
• Cervical cancer
• Breast cancer
• Hepatic adenoma
• OCPs are also considered the drug of choice for managing hirsutism and acne.

questions.text: A 12 year old child afebrile with painless lesion in the knee is observed on X-ray imaging no histoey of trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brodie's abscess  
Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic bone infection presenting as a painless, well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim, often in the metaphysis of long bones like the tibia or femur. It may occur without fever or trauma and has subtle symptoms. Other options like aneurysmal bone cyst, chondroblastoma, or simple bone cyst are less likely, as they typically present with pain, swelling, or different imaging features.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the chest X-ray of a sand mine worker?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Silicosis 
Eggshell calcification around lymph nodes is a characteristic radiological finding, often seen in silicosis. In a sand mine worker, this finding strongly suggests silicosis, a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust. Although other conditions like sarcoidosis or coal worker's pneumoconiosis can also show eggshell calcification, the occupational history of sand mining makes silicosis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following hernia is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paraumbilical hernia
A paraumbilical hernia is a type of abdominal hernia that occurs near—but not directly within—the navel. It is most common in adults, especially women, those who are overweight, or individuals with increased abdominal pressure.

choices.text: Sugical exploration with T Tube placement

questions.text: A patient underwent Laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 7 days later she presented to the hospital with pain in the right upper abdomen associated with fever. Ultrasonography showed 200 cc of collection in the subhepatic space. What would be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 US guided catheter drainage 
Given signs of infection (fever, pain) and a subhepatic biloma collection, the next step is ultrasound-guided catheter drainage along with antibiotics. Antibiotics alone won’t evacuate the fluid; surgical exploration is too invasive for an acute, contained complication; and a wait-and-watch approach risks worsening infection or bile peritonitis.

choices.text: At 3 cm behind the anterior fontanelle
3 cm Anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Between the anterior and posterior fontanelles

questions.text: During assisted vaginal delivery, where is the vacuum device typically applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3 cm Anterior to the posterior fontanelle
The vacuum device is typically placed on the "flexion point" of the fetal head.
This point is precisely located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel.
Alternatively, it can be described as 6 cm posterior to the anterior fontanel.
Placing the cup at this point helps to maintain the head in flexion, which allows the smaller diameters of the fetal head to emerge during delivery.
For correct placement, the perimeter or margin of the cup should touch the posterior fontanel, as the goal is to be close to the occiput.
The posterior fontanel is triangular, while the anterior fontanel is rhomboid.

choices.text: Perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and monitor

questions.text: A patient with a previous cesarean section is in labor with contractions of 3/10 (mild contractions), no fetal distress, and the membranes are intact. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and monitor
For a patient with a previous Cesarean section experiencing slow labor progress (indicated by the graph being to the right of the alert line), with intact membranes and no signs of fetal distress, the next appropriate step in management is to perform Artificial Rupture of Membranes (ARM). ARM helps to augment labor by releasing prostaglandins.
• Oxytocin augmentation is typically avoided as the first step in patients with a previous Cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.
• Instrumental delivery is usually reserved for the second stage of labor, not the active phase, and is not yet indicated.
• A repeat Cesarean section is not indicated at this point as there is no immediate distress, and the aim is to facilitate vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 patient diagnosed with severe endometriosis shows pelvic adhesions on laparoscopy. She has undergone tubal ligation and adhesiolysis previously. What is the most appropriate management during laparoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Total Laproscopic hysterectomy
For severe, recurrent endometriosis after prior treatment and with families complete, hysterectomy is a last resort since the disease originates in the uterus. Routine salpingo-oophorectomy is generally not recommended for women under 50 due to induced menopause and related risks, unless specifically desired by the patient. Medical therapy (e.g., GnRH agonists) or repeat adhesiolysis may be considered for milder cases or when fertility is still desired, but these are not definitive long-term solutions in patients who have completed childbearing.

questions.text: Which gene type is most commonly mutated in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC), a common inherited colorectal cancer syndrome characterized by early-onset colorectal cancer and increased risk of other malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MMR
Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) is caused by germline mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes, most often MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, or PMS2. Defective MMR leads to microsatellite instability and a high lifetime risk of colorectal cancer plus other malignancies. This autosomal dominant condition is the most common inherited colorectal cancer syndrome, with early-onset disease and familial clustering.

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone marked by the arrow in the given X-ray :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The navicular bone is one of the tarsal bones located in the midfoot. It is situated medially, just in front of the talus and behind the cuneiform bones. On an X-ray, the navicular appears as a boat-shaped bone and is an important structure for foot stability and movement. Arrow in the given X-ray points to this bone, the correct identification is the navicular.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding in a Gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Left Gastric artery 
Gastric ulcers most commonly bleed from vessels near the lesser curvature, especially the left gastric artery. The right gastroepiploic artery and the right gastric artery are less likely sources.

choices.text: To expedite the second stage of labor

questions.text: What is the primary aim of the shown maneuver during delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 To prevent perineal trauma
This maneuver is the Modified Ritgen's maneuver.
Its primary aim is to prevent perineal trauma.
This is achieved by controlling the rate of head delivery. The hand on the occiput provides counter-pressure to keep the head in flexion, preventing a rapid and uncontrolled extension that could lead to perineal tears.
Other strategies to prevent perineal tears include perineal massage, providing good perineal support, and applying warm compresses.
It's important to note that routine episiotomy is not recommended.

questions.text: An patient after cricket ball injury. The radiological image show is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Blowout fracture of the orbit  
A patient who has suffered a cricket ball injury and exhibits a "tear-drop sign" on radiological imaging as shown is most likely experiencing an orbital blowout fracture. This sign refers to the herniation of intraorbital fat, and possibly the inferior rectus muscle, through a fracture in the orbital floor into the maxillary sinus.

choices.text: Intestinal columnar epithelium to squamous metaplasia
Gastric foveolar epithelium to squamous metaplasia
Squamous epithelium to intestinal columnar metaplasia with goblet cells
Squamous epithelium to simple cuboidal epithelium

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with 7 years of chronic reflux has Barrett’s esophagus on endoscopy. Which histologic change is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Squamous epithelium to intestinal columnar metaplasia with goblet cells 
Barrett's esophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium lining the lower esophagus with columnar epithelium, specifically intestinal-type metaplasia.
