Intestinal metaplasia is a change in which the lining cells of an organ take on characteristics of intestinal cells, often including goblet cells. This change is often a protective response to chronic irritation from acid reflux (GERD). The squamous lining of the esophagus is vulnerable to acid damage, and the replacement with columnar epithelium, which is typically found in the intestines, makes the lining more resilient to stomach acid.

questions.text: A young child presents with cyanosis with shown radiological image. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for cyanosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  
TOF, the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, involves VSD, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and RV hypertrophy. These cause a right-to-left shunt, leading to cyanosis. On X-ray, it shows a "boot-shaped" heart due to RVH and reduced lung blood flow. Other options are less likely: TAPVC shows a "snowman" shape, ASD usually causes increased pulmonary flow without cyanosis, and Epstein anomaly affects the tricuspid valve with box shaped heart association with Lithium.

questions.text: The electron volt (eV) is a unit of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Energy 
An electron volt (eV) is a unit of energy. It is defined as the amount of kinetic energy gained or lost by an electron when it is accelerated through an electric potential difference of one volt. Since it measures energy, it is commonly used in atomic and particle physics to express small amounts of energy associated with particles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and tenesmus. He has a known diagnosis of ulcerative colitis for the past 3 years. Over the past 3 days, he has developed pain, redness, and photophobia in his right eye. His HLAB27 test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely extraintestinal manifestation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Uveitis 
The most likely extraintestinal manifestation is Uveitis, because the patient's symptoms of eye pain, redness, and photophobia are classic signs of uveitis, an inflammatory condition of the eye that frequently occurs in patients with ulcerative colitis, especially those with a positive HLA-B27 gene.

questions.text: A 16 year old boy presents with multiple episodes of abdominal pain and a history of passing blood in stools. On examination, he has dark pigmented spots on his lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Peutz Jeghers Syndrome 
The most likely diagnosis for the patient is Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the STK11 tumor suppressor gene. It features multiple nonmalignant hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the small intestine, which can cause obstruction, intussusception, abdominal pain, infarction, and chronic bleeding. Characteristic mucocutaneous signs include dark blue-gray or brown pigmented macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, palms, and soles. Lesions may be sessile, pedunculated, or lobulated, and the condition confers an increased risk of several malignancies.

choices.text: Surgical removal of the cyst along with Resection of intestine and anastomosis

questions.text: A female patient presented to the hospital where in she was diagnosed with an 8cm chylolymphatic mesenteric cyst. What would be the most appropriate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enucleation 
Enucleation is preferred because chylolymphatic cysts have their own blood supply, allowing careful dissection from the mesentery without removing adjacent bowel. The cyst can often be enucleated laparoscopically, sealing its independent vessels while preserving bowel perfusion. If the cyst is too entangled with the intestine’s blood supply, bowel resection may be necessary, though this is a safety measure rather than the main aim.

questions.text: Which imaging modality is most appropriate for evaluating the urinary tract in the following scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)  
IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram) involves injecting contrast dye into a vein to X-ray the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, helping diagnose stones, tumors, and obstructions. MCUG (Voiding Cystourethrogram) uses a catheter to fill the bladder with contrast, then takes X-rays during urination to detect issues like vesicoureteral reflux or urethral abnormalities. IVP assesses the entire urinary tract, while MCUG focuses on bladder and urethral function during voiding.

questions.text: A 60 year old lady presented to the OPD where on clinical examination she had a hard irregular lump inside the breast with dimpling of the overlying skin. Which of the following can be involved leading to dimpling of skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cooper’s ligaments 
Dimpling of the skin, also known as skin tethering or puckering, is a classic sign of breast cancer caused by the involvement of Cooper's ligaments. Cooper’s ligaments are connective tissue bands that span the breast, attaching tissue to the skin and chest muscles. If a tumor grows, it can cause fibrosis and invasion of these ligaments, shortening them and pulling the skin inward to create a dimple or puckering. Dimpling due to ligament shortening is a strong sign of a potential malignancy.

questions.text: A child with shown IVP image is given. Diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Ureterocele 
A ureterocele is a congenital dilation of the distal ureter entering the bladder. On IVP, it appears as a round filling defect with a surrounding halo, known as the "cobra head sign," often accompanied by hydronephrosis or displacement of the kidney pole in duplicated systems. Other options are less likely: ureter duplication involves multiple ureters but doesn't show the characteristic sign; posterior urethral valves cause bladder outlet obstruction without the cobra head appearance; and vesicoureteral reflux involves urine backflow, not the cystic dilation seen in ureterocele. The presence of the cobra head sign makes ureterocele the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has developed breast development and pubic hair. The mother wants to know which sign of puberty will typically occur next. Which of the following is the most likely next sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

peak height
Sequence of puberty signs:
In girls, after thelarche (breast development) and pubarche (pubic hair), the next typical sign is a rapid increase in height—the peak height velocity. Menarche (first menses) occurs after the peak height velocity, and axillary hair or vaginal discharge appear later in puberty.
In girls:
• The first sign is the growth spurt, an initial rapid increase in height before other visible changes.
• Thelarche follows, marking the development of breast tissue.
• Next comes pubarche, the appearance of pubic hair.
• Then peak height velocity occurs, representing a sudden or maximal acceleration in height growth.
• Finally, menarche, the first menstrual period, occurs.

In boys:
• The first sign is testicular enlargement.
• This is followed by penile enlargement.
• Next comes pubarche, the development of pubic hair.
• Height growth then reaches its maximum later in puberty.

questions.text: A patient has been in prolonged labor, and a tight ring is observed on abdominal examination. What is this ring called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bandl's ring
Bandl’s ring is a pathologic retraction ring seen as a constriction between the upper and lower uterus in obstructed labor. Schroeder’s ring, contraction ring, and physiological constriction ring are not indicative of obstruction. The definitive management of obstructed labor is cesarean section; destructive procedures are no longer used.

choices.text: Wait for 2 more hours and continue the ongoing treatment
Switch from crystalloid infusion to Colloid infusion
Give additional bolus of Hartman’s solution
Consider referral of this patient to higher centre

questions.text: A patient was admitted in the burn ward of the hospital with 30% burns where in he was resuscitated with the fluid calculated as per the Parkland formula. After 6 hours of fluid resuscitation he was still having cool extremities with a blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg, his urine output was 0.3ml/kg/hour. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Give additional bolus of Hartman’s solution 
This patient is in burn shock despite initial resuscitation with the Parkland formula, indicating inadequate fluid therapy. The next step is to increase the rate of crystalloid infusion and reassess the patient's response. To manage burn shock, titration of intravenous fluids is guided by clinical endpoints, with urine output as the primary target. If urine output falls below the desired level, progressively increase the infusion rate of crystalloids (Hartmann's solution) by 20–30% and reassess the patient’s response hourly. While an additional bolus (Option C) may provide a temporary increase, it does not address the sustained requirement for a higher ongoing fluid rate.

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with following Uterine anomaly. This pathology happens due to problem of which duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Para mesonephric duct
The paramesonephric duct, also known as the Mullerian duct, is responsible for giving rise to the female internal genitalia. Anomalies in its development can lead to conditions like a unicornuate uterus, where one duct develops normally while the other is rudimentary.

• The mesonephric duct (or Wolffian duct) forms the male internal genitalia, which include the seminal vesicles, ejaculatory ducts, epididymis, and ductus deferens.
• The urogenital sinus is involved in the formation of the external genitalia and the lower two-thirds of the vagina.
• Other uterine anomalies mentioned include:
1. Normal uterus: Characterized by no dip in the fundus.
2. Didelphys uterus: Both ducts develop separately, each having its own cervix, often associated with a double vagina or vaginal septum.
3. Arcuate uterus: Appears normal externally with no dip but has a small dip inside the cavity; it usually does not affect obstetric or gynecological outcomes and is considered an embryological variant.
4. Unicornuate uterus: Often seen on hysterosalpingography (HSG) as a banana-shaped uterus deviated to one side. It is associated with conditions like ectopic pregnancy and ectopic ovary.
5. Bicornuate uterus: Features only one cervix and a deep dip in the external contour.
6. Septate uterus: Has an absolutely normal external contour but contains a septum, leading to two cavities and usually one cervix.

questions.text: Identify the modality:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mammography 
Shown modality of Mammography uses low-energy X-rays to examine the breast for early detection of cancer, identifying masses, microcalcifications, and tissue distortions. It employs specialized equipment to highlight subtle tissue changes. On mammograms, fatty tissue appears darker, while dense tissue and tumors appear brighter. Guidelines from various organizations on mammography screening ages and frequency for women at average risk of breast cancer vary slightly, but generally recommend starting around age 40.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment would be recommended in a patient who has been suffering from epigastric pain off and on for quite some time, where in on investigations Urea breath test was positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amoxicillin, Clarithromycin and Omeprazole 
A patient with epigastric pain and a positive Urea Breath Test (UBT) has a Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. A positive UBT directly indicates an active H. pylori infection in the stomach. The recommended treatment for H. pylori is a combination therapy that includes a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and at least two antibiotics to kill the bacteria and reduce stomach acid.  Based on standard guidelines, the correct treatment is D. Amoxycillin, Clarithromycin and Omeprazole.

choices.text: Cover with a gauze soaked in normal saline and transfer to NICU
Apply a silo bag to protect the contents
Take to the operating theatre for immediate closure of the abdominal wall

questions.text: A newborn at CHC presents with protrusion of abdominal contents through the abdominal wall, without a covering membrane. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cover with a gauze soaked in normal saline and transfer to NICU  
The first priority is protecting the exposed bowel from injury, fluid loss, and infection. This is done by covering the protruding contents with a sterile, saline-soaked dressing. To minimize heat loss and prevent hypothermia, wrap the infant in a plastic bowel bag up to the axilla after the bowel is covered. Additional essential initial steps include inserting an orogastric tube for gastric decompression, establishing IV access for fluids and antibiotics, and assessing and securing the airway.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following a stab injury, with a penetrating wound in the abdomen. Patient vital parameters are stable. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

eFAST 
For a hemodynamically stable patient with a penetrating abdominal stab wound, the next step in management is an eFAST exam (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma). This ultrasound is used as a screening tool to assess for intraperitoneal fluid (blood), pneumothorax, or hemothorax. This exam is rapid, non-invasive, and helps guide the clinical decision of whether further management can be conservative or if more advanced imaging or surgery is required.

questions.text: In a case of macrosomic baby with shoulder dystocia, what is the first maneuver typically performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

McRobert's maneuver
The first maneuver recommended for shoulder dystocia is the McRoberts maneuver. McRoberts maneuver involves a sudden flexion and abduction of the maternal thighs onto the maternal abdomen. This maneuver does not change the actual dimensions of the pelvis but increases the available space by rotating the symphysis pubis cephalad, which in turn flattens the sacral promontory.If McRoberts fails, the next step is to apply suprapubic pressure while maintaining the McRoberts position. If these external maneuvers are unsuccessful, internal rotational maneuvers such as delivery of the posterior arm, Wood's corkscrew maneuver, or Rubin's maneuver are performed. These typically require more expertise.
The Zavanelli maneuver is a last-resort maneuver where the fetal head is pushed back into the uterus, followed by an immediate Cesarean section.
Cleidotomy (surgical cutting of the anterior clavicle) is a destructive procedure, rarely performed in modern obstetrics and usually as a final resort for shoulder dystocia.
It is crucial to never apply fundal pressure and to instruct the woman not to push during shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: A 13 year old boy was brought by the mother to the hospital with complaints of pain in the scrotum within 6 hours. On examination there was redness and swelling of the scrotum and cremasteric reflex was absent. What is the most appropriate next step in this boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Immediate scrotal exploration and derotation 
A 13-year-old boy presenting with sudden, severe scrotal pain, redness, swelling, and an absent cremasteric reflex has a classic presentation of testicular torsion. This condition is a surgical emergency, and the most appropriate next step is Immediate scrotal exploration and derotation.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with multiple fractures with bucket handle injury seen and the parents report a single fall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Battered Baby Syndrome 
Multiple fractures in a young infant, especially characteristic Classic Metaphyseal Lesions (CMLs) /(bucket handle fractures), along with injuries in different healing stages, suggest non-accidental trauma. Posterior rib fractures, scapular, sternal, or spinous process fractures are highly specific for abuse. A single fall unlikely causes such widespread injuries in a non-ambulatory 2-week-old. These findings strongly indicate battered baby syndrome.

questions.text: What is a co-test in cervical cancer screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HPV+PAPS 

The co-test combines HPV testing with a Pap smear, offering high sensitivity (HPV) and high specificity (Pap). In resource-rich countries, screening intervals are about every 5 years. For resource-limited settings per WHO: start at age 30, with HPV testing as the preferred method (every 5–10 years); VIA (every 3 years) as the second-best option, and Pap smear also every 3 years. Screening typically ends around age 50, and VIA is considered the most cost-effective method.

questions.text: A patient comes with Antepartum Haemorrhage. Her previous USG shows her having placenta previa. On doppler Placenta was seen adhered to the uterus and had perforated and entered the bladder. What is this pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Placenta percreta

In this patient's case, the Doppler shows the placenta not only adhered to the uterus but also having perforated and entered the bladder, which is a hallmark of placenta percreta.

questions.text: A woman with a history of previous preterm birth and one miscarriage presents for cervical length assessment. Ultrasound shows a short cervix, and a suture was applied to prevent preterm labor. Which type of cerclage was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Modified Shirodkar cerclage
McDonald cerclage uses a purse-string, non-absorbable suture (not tape). Shirodkar cerclage uses circular tape placed high near the internal os and requires anterior/posterior cervical incisions with bladder dissection to protect the bladder. Modified Shirodkar also uses circular tape with anterior/posterior incisions but avoids bladder dissection, making it quicker and less invasive. Emergency cerclage is for late presenting cases with bulging membranes and a fully dilated cervix; membranes are pushed back first. Upper gestational limit: emergency up to 28 weeks; elective typically up to 24 weeks.

questions.text: A woman is bleeding profusely during a cesarean section. After administration of oxytocin, what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Compression sutures
For profuse bleeding, particularly atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), occurring during a Cesarean section with an open abdomen and after oxytocin has been administered, the immediate next step is to apply compression sutures.
B-Lynch sutures are a common type of compression suture applied directly to the uterus to compress it internally and control bleeding.
Balloon tamponade is typically used for vaginal deliveries or when the abdomen is not open.
Uterine artery ligation or hysterectomy are more aggressive interventions that would be considered if the patient's vital signs are unstable or if compression sutures fail to control the bleeding.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in 2nd ICS

questions.text: An adult patient was brought to the emergency following a road traffic accident with breathing difficulty. On auscultation breath sounds were absent on one side and there was mediastinal shift. What would be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wide bore needle insertion in 2nd ICS 
Wide bore needle insertion in 2nd ICS to relieve a life-threatening tension pneumothorax. Breath sounds absent on one side with mediastinal shift is a classic sign of a tension pneumothorax, a medical emergency that requires immediate decompression with a needle before a definitive chest tube is placed.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindication to subcutaneous implant/IUD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Undiagnosed genital bleeding
For both subcutaneous progesterone implants and IUDs, undiagnosed uterine or vaginal bleeding is a contraindication.
- Hypertension: oral combined pills are contraindicated, but progestin-only methods (implants, most IUDs) are generally acceptable.
- Diabetes: combined OCPs are often contraindicated; progesterone-only devices or IUDs can be used.
- PID history: not a contraindication to IUDs; current PID is.
- Other IUD contraindications: suspected pregnancy, uterine abnormalities or distorted cavities, current pelvic infection, Wilson’s disease (copper IUD), and breast cancer (specifically with Mirena)

questions.text: A patient presents with severe headache. A CT scan of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage 
Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) appears on CT as high-density blood in the subarachnoid spaces, often causing a sudden, severe headache. Meningitis may show mild CT changes or meningeal enhancement with symptoms like fever, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Brain abscess presents as ring-enhancing lesions with headache and neurological deficits. Epidural hematoma shows a biconvex hyperdense mass between skull and dura, often after head trauma, with a possible lucid interval. CT imaging is essential to distinguish these conditions in patients with severe headache.

questions.text: A 2 year-old boy was brought to the hospital with a painless swelling in the right scrotum associated with redness. The swelling is present since birth and was reducible earlier but now has become irreducible. What can be the likely pathology in this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Strangulated inguinal hernia 
The likely pathology is Strangulated inguinal hernia. This is a medical emergency that occurs when a hernia that was previously reducible (could be pushed back in) becomes incarcerated (trapped) and its blood supply is cut off.

choices.text: Take the patient for surgery for release of contracture
Mobilise and Start physiotherapy under supervision

questions.text: A patient suffered from 40% burns of 3rd degree over the arm, following which he was treated in the hospital where split thickness skin grafting surgery was done. He developed stiffness at the graft site in 7 to 10 days. Which of the following next step would you recommend in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Mobilise and Start physiotherapy under supervision 
Early mobilization within 7–10 days after grafting supports graft take and helps prevent contractures. In the subacute phase, the aim is to maintain joint movement, reduce swelling, and prevent tight scar tissue through active and active-assisted range of motion, proper positioning, and splinting. Scar tissue from deep burns and full-thickness grafts tightens over time, but mobilization guides collagen alignment to produce a more flexible scar. Delaying mobilization increases the risk of contractures and may necessitate additional surgery later.
